conversation.content: Hello doctor, I lost consciousness about an hour ago.
What were you doing at the time when you lost consciousness?
I was sitting at home and resting. I wasn’t doing anything special. Suddenly, I just didn’t know anything anymore. When my family found me, I was drenched in sweat and my face didn’t look right.
When you lost consciousness, were there other people around? About how long did it last, and were there any other accompanying symptoms during that time?

I was sitting at home resting, and my family was nearby. The loss of consciousness lasted for a few minutes, but I’m not exactly sure how long. I was sweating a lot and my face was pale. There were no convulsions and no loss of bowel or bladder control. My family said my eyes rolled upward, but there was no jaw clenching or shaking of my arms or legs.
Have you had any other illnesses in the past?
I have high blood pressure and asthma. I’ve never had diabetes. Other than that, I haven’t had any serious illnesses, just occasional minor problems.
When you exercise or do physical work, have you ever felt any discomfort?

In the past, sometimes when I was active I would feel tightness in my throat, with some chest tightness and shortness of breath. It didn’t happen every time. Usually, resting for a while or taking some medicine would make it better. In the past few days, this has been happening more often. Walking a bit faster can bring it on, and sometimes I break out in a sweat and feel pain in my back. I didn’t pay much attention to it and didn’t see a doctor.
Have you already had an electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac biomarker tests?

The ECG showed sinus rhythm, but there was second-degree type I atrioventricular block. Some leads were abnormal. For example, leads II, III, and aVF showed qR waveforms, with mild ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversion. The ST segments in leads V7 to V9 were also elevated, with T-wave inversion. The specific values are recorded by the doctor.

Cardiac biomarkers were not tested, so there are no results available.
What were the results of your cardiac monitoring?

The cardiac monitor showed that my heart rate was relatively slow, around the low 50s per minute. The rhythm was sinus rhythm, but atrioventricular block would occur at times, specifically second-degree type I. There were no obvious episodes of malignant arrhythmias, but overall the heart rate was slow, and the doctors have been monitoring it closely.

Diagnosis:
1. Conclusion: Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
    Cardiogenic shock
   Reasoning: Post-exertional chest pain and syncope; ST–T changes in inferior and posterior leads on ECG; risk factors including advanced age, male sex, and hypertension.

2. Conclusion: Hypertension
   Reasoning: Past medical history
Treatment:
1. Loading-dose dual antiplatelet therapy

2. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (primary PCI)

3. Post-procedure cardiac monitoring, repeat ECGs, and completion of echocardiography to assess cardiac structure, function, and mechanical complications.

4. Secondary prevention medications: dual antiplatelet therapy (>1 year), statins, and antihypertensive agents (if no contraindications, consider angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor [ARNI] or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor [ACEI] as part of the antihypertensive regimen). Monitor blood pressure and lipid levels, conduct regular outpatient follow-up, and repeat blood tests, biochemistry panels, and ECGs as needed.
